No. No it is not. It might be when you have the most energy, but I can assure you that many of us are the exact opposite. I can't do shit first thing in the morning, right after rolling out of bed. My energy peaks in the evening and at night. lead up until bed-time. Which is frustrating because sometimes it's hard to fall asleep because my mind is buzzing and I'm all wired thinking about "stuff". But there's no question that my most effective time for studying / writing / coding / etc. is at night.

Dear mr, i'm currently having a 9 to 5 job and i really want to study math to boost my career. I try to read math book and study every night and make it hobby. But i can not keep the discipline for more than a week and just keep coming back to playing video game. Do you have any recommendations for quitting game, distracting stuffs and replacing them with math and studying ? Thank you.

Reply: You need to practice discipline. Any time you are tempted to do something besides what you are supposed to be doing, you are practicing discipline and having control of your own mind and that is a good thing. The more you do it, the easier it gets, though you will always be tested, and that will never stop.

Once you master discipline and controlling your mind to a certain degree it is very empowering!
Reply: learn to embrace necessary suffering until it becomes not-suffering. That’s basically what discipline is

I am from crypto space. I am trying to learn the math behind zero-knowledge proof. It is so freaking hard! After quitting school for so many years, i can't even remember what polynomial is. Btw, what books would you recommend to seriously study the math behind modern cryptography ?

Reply: I recommend the book by Trappe and Washington. It is called Introduction to Cryptography with Coding Theory. It's kind of expensive and it's not perfect but, I did read the entire book and I thought it was "easy" compared to other high lvl math books. Note this was Pre-Bitcoin. I hope this helps my friend! Cryptography is a beautiful subject!

Reply: If he can't even remember what a polinomial is, isn't he should start with some algebra?

Reply: @@TheMathSorcerer When i was doing math back in the day in school, i always memorise the formula and plug in the number so i can get the result and pass the exam. But now i find myself completely lost when it comes to really understanding the why and what of the math. I can't get the intuition why the math is done this way. I feel totally upset. How much effort do i have to put in to get to that level?

Reply: A good place to start mathematically if you’re willing to work is Apostols Calculus. It will introduce you to proof writing and higher math ideas but will also teach calculus. For elementary math it doesn’t really matter, any decent high school algebra + geometry textbook will be fine
